examples.headline: a
examples.description: The HTML <a> element (or anchor element) creates a hyperlink to other web pages, files, locations within the same page, email addresses, or any other URL. MDN web docs: <a>: The Anchor element
examples.example:
Link to Named Anchor
Named Anchor

examples.headline: abbr
examples.description: The HTML Abbreviation element(<abbr>) represents an abbreviation or acronym; the optional title attribute can provide an expansion or description for the abbreviation. If present, title must contain this full description and nothing else. MDN web docs: <abbr>: The Abbreviation element
examples.example: Using <abbr title="HyperText Markup Language">HTML</abbr> is fun and easy!

examples.headline: b
examples.description: The HTML Bring Attention To element (<b>)  is used to draw the reader's attention to the element's contents, which are not otherwise granted special importance. This was formerly known as the Boldface element, and most browsers still draw the text in boldface. However, you should not use <b> for styling text; instead, you should use the CSS font-weight property to create boldface text, or the <strong> element to indicate that text is of special importance. MDN web docs: <b>: The Bring Attention To element
examples.example: This article describes several text-level elements.

examples.headline: bdi
examples.description:
The HTML Bidirectional Isolate element (<bdi>)  tells the browser's bidirectional algorithm to treat the text it contains in isolation from its surrounding text. It's particularly useful when a website dynamically inserts some text and doesn't know the directionality of the text being inserted.

MDN web docs: <bdi>: The Bidirectional Isolate element
examples.example:
اَلأَعْشَى - 1st place
Jerry Cruncher - 2nd place

examples.headline: bdo
examples.description: The HTML Bidirectional Text Override element (<bdo>) overrides the current directionality of text, so that the text within is rendered in a different direction.MDN web docs: <bdo>: The Bidirectional Text Override element
examples.example:
This text will go left to right.

This text will go right to left.

examples.headline: br
examples.description: The HTML <br> element produces a line break in text (carriage-return). It is useful for writing a poem or an address, where the division of lines is significant. MDN web docs: <br>: The Line Break element
examples.example:
Mozilla
331 E. Evelyn Avenue
Mountain View, CA
94041
USA

examples.headline: cite
examples.description: The HTML Citation element (<cite>) is used to describe a reference to a cited creative work, and must include the title of that work. The reference may be in an abbreviated form according to context-appropriate conventions related to citation metadata. MDN web docs: <cite>: The Citation element
examples.example: More information can be found in <cite>[ISO-0000]</cite>.

examples.headline: code
examples.description: The HTML <code> element displays its contents styled in a fashion intended to indicate that the text is a short fragment of computer code. By default, the content text is displayed using the user agent's default monospace font. MDN web docs: <code>: The Inline Code element
examples.example: The function selectAll() highlights all the text in the input field so the user can, for example, copy or delete the text.

examples.headline: data
examples.description: The HTML <data> element links a given content with a machine-readable translation. If the content is time- or date-related, the <time> element must be used. MDN web docs: <data>: The Machine-Readable data element
examples.example:
New Products

  • Mini Ketchup
  • Jumbo Ketchup
  • Mega Jumbo Ketchup

examples.headline: dfn
examples.description: The HTML Definition element (<dfn>) is used to indicate the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence. The <p> element, the <dt>/<dd> pairing, or the <section> element which is the nearest ancestor of the <dfn> is considered to be the definition of the term. MDN web docs: <dfn>: The Definition element
examples.example:
The HTML Definition element (<dfn>) is used to indicate the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence.

The HST is among the most productive scientific instruments ever constructed.

examples.headline: em
examples.description: The HTML <em> element marks text that has stress emphasis. The <em> element can be nested, with each level of nesting indicating a greater degree of emphasis. MDN web docs: <em>: The Emphasis element
examples.example: In HTML 5, what was previously called block-level content is now called flow content.

examples.headline: i
examples.description: The HTML <i> element represents a range of text that is set off from the normal text for some reason. Some examples include technical terms, foreign language phrases, or fictional character thoughts. It is typically displayed in italic type. MDN web docs: <i>: The Set-off Text element
examples.example: The Latin phrase Veni, vidi, vici is often mentioned in music, art, and literature.

examples.headline: kbd
examples.description: The HTML Keyboard Input element (<kbd>) represents a span of inline text denoting textual user input from a keyboard, voice input, or any other text entry device. By convention, the user agent defaults to rendering the contents of a <kbd> element using its default monospace font, although this is not mandated by the HTML standard. MDN web docs: <kbd>: The Keyboard Input element
examples.example: Use the command <kbd>help mycommand</kbd> to view documentation for the command "mycommand".

examples.headline: mark
examples.description: The HTML Mark Text element (<mark>) represents text which is marked or highlighted for reference or notation purposes, due to the marked passage's relevance or importance in the enclosing context. MDN web docs: <mark>: The Mark Text element
examples.example: It is a dark time for the Rebellion. Although the Death Star has been destroyed, <mark>Imperial</mark> troops have driven the Rebel forces from their hidden base and pursued them across the galaxy.

examples.headline: q
examples.description: The HTML <q> element indicates that the enclosed text is a short inline quotation. Most modern browsers implement this by surrounding the text in quotation marks. This element is intended for short quotations that don't require paragraph breaks; for long quotations use the <blockquote> element. MDN web docs: <q>: The Inline Quotation element
examples.example: According to Mozilla's website, <q cite="https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/about/history/details/">Firefox 1.0 was released in 2004 and became a big success.</q>

examples.headline: s
examples.description: The HTML <s> element renders text with a strikethrough, or a line through it. Use the <s> element to represent things that are no longer relevant or no longer accurate. However, <s> is not appropriate when indicating document edits; for that, use the <del> and <ins> elements, as appropriate. MDN web docs: <s>: The Strikethrough element
examples.example: <s>Today's Special: Salmon</s> SOLD OUT

examples.headline: samp
examples.description: The HTML Sample Element (<samp>) is used to enclose inline text which represents sample (or quoted) output from a computer program. Its contents are typically rendered using the browser's default monospaced font (such as Courier or Lucida Console). MDN web docs: <samp>: The Sample Output element
examples.example: When the process is complete, the utility will output the text Scan complete. Found N results. You can then proceed to the next step.

examples.headline: small
examples.description: The HTML <small> element makes the text font size one size smaller (for example, from large to medium, or from small to x-small) down to the browser's minimum font size.  In HTML5, this element is repurposed to represent side-comments and small print, including copyright and legal text, independent of its styled presentation. MDN web docs: <small>: The Small element
examples.example: This is the first sentence. <small>This whole sentence is in small letters.</small>

examples.headline: span
examples.description: The HTML <span> element is a generic inline container for phrasing content, which does not inherently represent anything. It can be used to group elements for styling purposes (using the class or id attributes), or because they share attribute values, such as lang. It should be used only when no other semantic element is appropriate. <span> is very much like a <div> element, but <div> is a block-level element whereas a <span> is an inline element. MDN web docs: <span>: The Small element
examples.example: Some text

examples.headline: strong
examples.description: The HTML Strong Importance Element (<strong>) indicates that its contents have strong importance, seriousness, or urgency. Browsers typically render the contents in bold type. MDN web docs: <strong>: The Small element
examples.example: Before proceeding, make sure you put on your safety goggles.

examples.headline: sub
examples.description: The HTML Subscript element (<sub>) specifies inline text which should be displayed as subscript for solely typographical reasons. Subscripts are typically rendered with a lowered baseline using smaller text. MDN web docs: <sub>: The Subscript element
examples.example: Almost every developer's favorite molecule is C<sub>8</sub>H<sub>10</sub>N<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, which is commonly known as "caffeine."

examples.headline: sup
examples.description: The HTML Superscript element (<sup>) specifies inline text which is to be displayed as superscript for solely typographical reasons. Superscripts are usually rendered with a raised baseline using smaller text. MDN web docs: <sup>: The Superscript element
examples.example: One of the most common equations in all of physics is <var>E</var>=<var>m</var><var>c</var><sup>2</sup>.

examples.headline: time
examples.description: The HTML <time> element represents a specific period in time. It may include the datetime attribute to translate dates into machine-readable format, allowing for better search engine results or custom features such as reminders. MDN web docs: <time>: The Time element
examples.example: The concert starts at <time datetime="2018-07-07T20:00:00">20:00</time>.

examples.headline: u
examples.description: The HTML Unarticulated Annotation Element (<u>) represents a span of inline text which should be rendered in a way that indicates that it has a non-textual annotation. This is rendered by default as a simple solid underline, but may be altered using CSS. MDN web docs: <u>: The Unarticulated Annotation element
examples.example: This paragraph includes a <u class="spelling">wrnogly</u> spelled word.

examples.headline: var
examples.description: The HTML Variable element (<var>) represents the name of a variable in a mathematical expression or a programming context. It's typically presented using an italicized version of the current typeface, although that behavior is browser-dependent. MDN web docs: <var>: The Variable element
examples.example: A simple equation: <var>x</var> = <var>y</var> + 2

examples.headline: wbr
examples.description: The HTML <wbr> element represents a word break opportunity—a position within text where the browser may optionally break a line, though its line-breaking rules would not otherwise create a break at that location. MDN web docs: <wbr>: The Word Break Opportunity element
examples.example: http://this<wbr>.is<wbr>.a<wbr>.really<wbr>.long<wbr>.example<wbr>.com/With<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages<wbr>/deeper<wbr>/level<wbr>/pages
